Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Situation2: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other like a slow-motion avalanche. My wife’s voice echoes in my mind—“Can you please fold these tonight? I’ve done the last three loads.” I promised I would, but now, as I sit at my desk in the control tower, my headset crackles with urgency. A major route closure has just been announced, and the radar screen blooms with holding patterns, flights circling in tight stacks, pilots requesting updates every few seconds. My supervisor expects me to keep the airspace safe and efficient, to make split-second decisions that could mean the difference between order and chaos. My phone buzzes in my pocket—a text from my wife, a gentle reminder about the laundry. My chest tightens. I want to be the partner she can rely on, but right now, dozens of planes depend on me, too. I grip the edge of the console, torn between the world at home and the one in the sky, both demanding more than I feel I can give.
